[{'created': '2017-12-19 14:13:47.000000000', 'message': "Drop django_openstack_auth master branch jobs

In Queens cycle, the code of django_openstack_auth was merged into
the horizon repository. The master branch of django_openstack_auth
will be retired.

This commit skips the jobs of django_openstack_auth for the master
branch. We still maintain the stable branches, so the jobs need to be kept.
Zuul project template does not support brances, so required project
templates are converted into jobs.

system-required template is kept as this is just a merge-check noop job.
publish-to-pypi is kept too as we don't release django_openstack_auth
from the master branch and there is no side effect.

Change-Id: I837c3426de1a18b4055dd7066743e427074425b3
"}]
commit_message:
Drop django_openstack_auth master branch jobs

In Queens cycle, the code of django_openstack_auth was merged into
the horizon repository. The master branch of django_openstack_auth
will be retired.

This commit skips the jobs of django_openstack_auth for the master
branch. We still maintain the stable branches, so the jobs need to be kept.
Zuul project template does not support brances, so required project
templates are converted into jobs.

system-required template is kept as this is just a merge-check noop job.
publish-to-pypi is kept too as we don't release django_openstack_auth
from the master branch and there is no side effect.

Change-Id: I837c3426de1a18b4055dd7066743e427074425b3

commit_message:
Remove deprecated ironic.common.policy.enforce()

This removes the method ironic.common.policy.enforce(). It was
deprecated in the Newton cycle and had been slated for removal
in Pike.

The deprecation happened in c7da7a69250fcffb6841d36710770608d603bb6a.

Change-Id: I540e88c49c792e39481123e7bf4f204fcd86da0b

commit_message:
Revert "Update static files"

The change of policy causes issues with heat and it is reproducible
using OSA AIO.

# sudo pip install python-heatclient
# openstack orchestration service list
ERROR: You are not authorized to use index.
# openstack stack list
ERROR: You are not authorized to use index.

This reverts commit 8fcd29197797eef409254605f0ce73ef8d1bda6b.

Change-Id: I84c56992db1a6ff8c5d71be5986aacad0099eb12

Thanks for the reviews. As for disable_root_before_enabled, are you suggesting that I should raise a NotFound exception when you do disable_before_root_enabled in this patch, cause that's not mentioned in the spec. And this bp allows you do 'root-disable' on a instance whether its 'root' has been enabled or not. There are also something about the root-disable I am curious, like when you do root-disable, the RootHistory of this instance should or should not be deleted. commit_message:
Retry connection to OVSDB from metadata agent

Right now, if the connection to SB database fails from the
metadata agent, the process would just exit.
With this patch, it will retry forever, waiting 2^x seconds
between each retry, up to a max of 180 seconds.

Change-Id: If7970cd48dce5467b7dd9fa2364f39fedfbf6302
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for Queens 2017-12-19

This patch updates all the roles to the latest available SHA's,
updates all the OpenStack Service SHA's and also updates the
appropriate python requirements pins.

Change-Id: I1e04455ad896525bbad349ac0369201b6036215f

commit_message:
Infer MACVLAN/IPVLAN ports

Add support to infer MACVLAN ports (and IPVLAN ports) from Neutron port
and allowed address pair specification.

Partial bug, since tests are still missing.

Partial-Bug: #1720734
Change-Id: I4e07f074b3db999d72bfa60bae1622ce9547c3e5

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-17 09:18:33.000000000', 'message': "Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html
.

Change-Id: I0919ad158b4d8cae993f5fd137d4759402d0851c
"}]
commit_message:
Remove setting of version/release from releasenotes

Release notes are version independent, so remove version/release
values. We've found that projects now require the service package
to be installed in order to build release notes, and this is entirely
due to the current convention of pulling in the version information.

Release notes should not need installation in order to build, so this
unnecessary version setting needs to be removed.

This is needed for new release notes publishing, see
I56909152975f731a9d2c21b2825b972195e48ee8 and the discussion starting
at
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-November/124480.html
.

Change-Id: I0919ad158b4d8cae993f5fd137d4759402d0851c

commit_message:
WIP: Manage metrics units in yaml configuration.

Allow users and operators to control the conversions units,
by filling source and destinations units for the metrics.
Differents units can now be affected to metrics from a same resource.

Task: 6077
Story: 2001396

Change-Id: I6ef2157f9351ca6f356b699e03e49428e98548db

commit_message:
Enable addition of proper headers in apache2

This patchset implements necessary actions which are required to
properly set headers when using SSL.

Change-Id: I78d6e5cadb398464ccec98f7ed2928668942f18b
Closes-Bug: #1736417
Depends-On: I8cf4c048835b85c0845083768ec2d66e940cb15f

commit_message:
Patch mkisofs calls

The nova unit tests recently started to fail on systems lacking mkisofs
(like mac osx). Skip these mkisofs calls by patching _make_iso9660.

Change-Id: I350aafa878616f74df506c1bc9ee5f26ea06fe97
Closes-Bug: #1630420

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-19 10:06:43.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: I6f9fb94e6a3bbd89d1e02bd006f7af3bf2797579
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: I6f9fb94e6a3bbd89d1e02bd006f7af3bf2797579

Sleep after service-disable can be replaced with force-down API call.
This patch removed the sleep and added force-down API call.

Implements: bp use-force-down-api

commit_message:
Use force-down API when host-failure recovery

Sleep after service-disable can be replaced with force-down API call.
This patch removed the sleep and added force-down API call.

Change-Id: Ib5c9f0dcb321b37875f51c0b109671970db77501
Implements: bp use-force-down-api

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-09-01 09:49:28.000000000', 'message': 'Adding BGPVPN OVO objects and tests

Bagpipe driver is moving toward using ovo objects for rpc calls.
The bgpvpn ovo objects are defined under networking_bagpipe/objects.
They overlay the bgpvpn database tables, and are intended for using rpc calls.

The corresponding tests have been implemented.

Testing needs a hook for BGPVPNNetAssociation, which has not been
implemented yet.

Co-Authored-By: Omar Sanhaji <sanhaji.omar@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Thomas Morin <thomas.morin@orange.com>

Partial Implements: blueprint bagpipe-bgpvpn-ovo

Change-Id: Ie0f1c9f3f2bd1cf317b921ee1c1691c2816d8832

commit_message:
Adding BGPVPN OVO objects and tests

This change adds OVO objects for networking-bgpvpn, tailored
for their only consumer, networking-bagpipe.

The corresponding tests are implemented.

Testing needs a hook for BGPVPNNetAssociation, which has not been
implemented yet.

Co-Authored-By: Omar Sanhaji <sanhaji.omar@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Thomas Morin <thomas.morin@orange.com>

Partial Implements: blueprint bagpipe-bgpvpn-ovo
Depends-On: Icb6a73aeca0286725c78a3bf403e1df895a34d4e
Change-Id: Ie0f1c9f3f2bd1cf317b921ee1c1691c2816d8832

commit_message:
check audit state when deleting audit

If audit is 'ONGOING' or 'PENDING', don't delete audit.

Change-Id: Iac714e7e78e7bb5b52f401e5b2ad0e1d8af8bb45
Closes-Bug: #1738358

commit_message:
Adding keystone notification listener support

Notification listener processes only keystone project delete events.
It uses keystone project id to identify if related barbican resources are there
and deletes that project related barbican resources.

10/07/2014: Keep resolving rebase conflicts as this change is pending for a while.
Modified listener transaction logic as per related recent change in barbican.
Fixed missing patcher stop in few places which was causing failure in new tests.

Implements: blueprint consume-keystone-events

Change-Id: Iba7d50eb222edd43352ef82f629df2b3187c76ec

commit_message:
Revert "Use push notification for security groups"

This reverts commit 020ea1479e3c2fac3e1ef99ed85f45792b286a0e.

The change made agents not create exchanges for old security group RPC
endpoints, which raises NotFound on server side.

Change-Id: If40678b59e539040d45a2ed1d484b9dddf20c500
Closes-Bug: #1707160

commit_message:
Fix BufferedReader writing zero size chunks

BufferedReader loops constantly writing zero-size chunks. This fixes the
bug writing zero sized chunks and terminates correctly.

Closes-Bug: #1738331
Change-Id: I7a480b366c9a9d56303f402915f13f1c76128e5c

Hrm, probably simpler to just run the doc job nuder python 3. Waiting for mordred'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2017-12-19 14:20:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

That was my other option with the releases job, but thought it would be safer for now to be py2/3 compatible. Just going with py3 in general going forward is probably a good thing though.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-12-20 07:41:43.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-19 10:41:14.000000000', 'message': 'Use io.open instead of open in extensions

Docs fail to build due to open() not having an "encoding" kwarg
when running under Python 2.7. This switches instances using it
to use io.open instead. This is slightly slower on py2, but we are
not using it in a way that should have a noticable impact.
With py3 it is just a pass through to the normal open() call.

Change-Id: Iccad49fbfae3fe68080e65d7a8f40b7554e8df2c
'}]
commit_message:
Use io.open instead of open in extensions

Docs fail to build due to open() not having an "encoding" kwarg
when running under Python 2.7. This switches instances using it
to use io.open instead. This is slightly slower on py2, but we are
not using it in a way that should have a noticable impact.
With py3 it is just a pass through to the normal open() call.

Change-Id: Iccad49fbfae3fe68080e65d7a8f40b7554e8df2c

[{'created': '2017-12-01 09:20:48.000000000', 'message': 'Fix status message inside validate_can_perform_action()

If we assign status with just self.db_info.task_status, we would get a
exception message like :
ERROR: Instance d6f3861d-21d2-4e96-9df1-64cf6439ea9c is not currently
available for an action to be performed (task status was (84 ERROR Build
error: guestagent timeout.)). (HTTP 422)

But here we actually need action only.

Change-Id: Iab69ba01937aa8e7a9be9e95e499d64891beed03
Signed-off-by: Fan Zhang <zh.f@outlook.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix status message inside validate_can_perform_action()

If we assign status with just self.db_info.task_status, we would get a
exception message like :
ERROR: Instance d6f3861d-21d2-4e96-9df1-64cf6439ea9c is not currently
available for an action to be performed (task status was (84 ERROR Build
error: guestagent timeout.)). (HTTP 422)

But here we actually need action only.

Change-Id: Iab69ba01937aa8e7a9be9e95e499d64891beed03
Signed-off-by: Fan Zhang <zh.f@outlook.com>

[{'created': '2017-10-17 16:40:28.000000000', 'message': 'Fix libvirt daemon name condition

This makes the condition that chooses which daemon name libvirt to call
the same as for choosing the livirt package names.

Without this fix the condition checking for a directory is incorrect
when livirt is not yet installed, but is used before installing the
packages.

Change-Id: Ib5eb12769128527a6f4b3b5f7674bd2dad0ed160
'}]
commit_message:
Fix libvirt daemon name condition

This makes the condition that chooses which daemon name libvirt to call
the same as for choosing the livirt package names.

Without this fix the condition checking for a directory is incorrect
when livirt is not yet installed, but is used before installing the
packages.

Change-Id: Ib5eb12769128527a6f4b3b5f7674bd2dad0ed160

recheck'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2017-09-28 14:30:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I do have a bit of a concern on this.  I think we should have puppet make sure that the contents of /var/log/nova are set to nova:nova.

The reason behind that is that in the case of an existing deployment which has a /var/log/nova/nova-manage.log ran under root, the Puppet run will fail.'}, {'account_id': 23942, 'date': '2017-10-08 17:16:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-10-08 18:20:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-29 09:24:55.000000000', 'message': "Run nova-manage commands as the nova user

When you execute nova-manage commands, oslo logs to the following
location (file name is dynamically created based on command name).

    /var/log/nova/nova-manage.log

Because puppet-nova is executing these commands as root,
nova-manage.log is owned by root:root, preventing the 'nova-manage
db archive_deleted_rows' entry in nova's crontab from executing.

    Permission denied: '/var/log/nova/nova-manage.log'

This log file is also an outlier, as all other log files in
/var/log/nova/ are owned by nova:nova.

Follow-up patches will need to chown this log file for the upgrade
case. It might also make sense to just explicitly touch this file
in the install case too since this bug keeps coming back.

Closes-Bug: #1671681
Change-Id: I0ca0110cbf9139c79074cf603dcab9135f96e765
"}, {'created': '2017-09-26 21:44:07.000000000', 'message': "Run nova-manage commands as the nova user

Change-Id: I0ca0110cbf9139c79074cf603dcab9135f96e765

    Permission denied: '/var/log/nova/nova-manage.log'

This log file is also an outlier, as all other log files in
/var/log/nova/ are owned by nova:nova.

Follow-up patches will need to chown this log file for the upgrade
case. It might also make sense to just explicitly touch this file
in the install case too since this bug keeps coming back.

Closes-Bug: #1671681
Change-Id: I0ca0110cbf9139c79074cf603dcab9135f96e765
"}, {'created': '2017-12-12 00:40:53.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Run nova-manage commands as the nova user

When you execute nova-manage commands, oslo logs to the following
location (file name is dynamically created based on command name).

    /var/log/nova/nova-manage.log

Because puppet-nova is executing these commands as root,
nova-manage.log is owned by root:root, preventing the 'nova-manage
db archive_deleted_rows' entry in nova's crontab from executing.

    Permission denied: '/var/log/nova/nova-manage.log'

This log file is also an outlier, as all other log files in
/var/log/nova/ are owned by nova:nova.

Closes-Bug: #1671681
Change-Id: I0ca0110cbf9139c79074cf603dcab9135f96e765

ownership of all nova logs is corrected before configuring nova.

commit_message:
Correct permissions on the nova logfiles

When you execute nova-manage commands, oslo logs to the following
location (file name is dynamically created based on command name).

    /var/log/nova/nova-manage.log

Because puppet-nova is executing these commands as root,
nova-manage.log is owned by root, preventing the 'nova-manage
db archive_deleted_rows' entry in nova's crontab from executing.

    Permission denied: '/var/log/nova/nova-manage.log'

This log file is also an outlier, as all other log files in
/var/log/nova/ are owned by nova:nova.

Similar issues are possible for other nova logs, if for example
a nova services is initially started manually as root, so the
ownership of all nova logs is corrected before configuring nova.

Co-Authored-By: Oliver Walsh <owalsh@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Diana Clarke <diana.joan.clarke@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Maciej Kucia <maciej@kucia.net>
Closes-Bug: #1671681
Change-Id: I0ca0110cbf9139c79074cf603dcab9135f96e765

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: I4f6d6420b62f5da9ca0973314ee0ba1cec9c4384

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-19 12:05:12.000000000', 'message': "Remove display_name and display_description parameters from snapshot API

Cinder V1 APIs are deprecated long back. Create/update snapshots were
accepting display_name and display_description parameters in the
request body but in v2/v3 these parameters are replaced by 'name' and
'description'. When this change was introduced, tempest tests were
not modified. Recently, we are adding schema support for v2/v3 APIs
[1] due to which tempest tests are failing as v2/v3 doesn't accept
display_name and display_description parameter in the request body.

This patch fixes failing test cases by passing 'name' parameter
instead of 'display_name' in request body.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/520991/

Change-Id: Icf4a5355134b4c7a9f102822c84d9c2404afa476
"}]
commit_message:
Remove display_name and display_description parameters from snapshot API

Cinder V1 APIs are deprecated long back. Create/update snapshots were
accepting display_name and display_description parameters in the
request body but in v2/v3 these parameters are replaced by 'name' and
'description'. When this change was introduced, tempest tests were
not modified. Recently, we are adding schema support for v2/v3 APIs
[1] due to which tempest tests are failing as v2/v3 doesn't accept
display_name and display_description parameter in the request body.

This patch fixes failing test cases by passing 'name' parameter
instead of 'display_name' in request body.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/520991/

Change-Id: Icf4a5355134b4c7a9f102822c84d9c2404afa476

subject: Temporarily add performance test cases for display
messages:
[{'account_id': 24714, 'date': '2017-02-09 08:18:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2017-02-09 08:19:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2017-02-09 08:26:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Do you want us to review this change already, or will you let us know when you are done? (you wrote "temporarily" in the commit message)'}, {'account_id': 24714, 'date': '2017-02-09 09:47:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Maybe the expression of "temporarily" is not very accurate.

We just want you to understand how we do the test by this change.

We're not going to push it into the git repository.

Thanks.'}, {'account_id': 21414, 'date': '2017-02-09 12:47:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> Hi,

 > bp.
 > 
 > I have no idea that whether it can be associated with the bp,
 > here's the bp link: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/vitrage/+spec/scenario-evaluator-performance-test

I would suggest submit patch to the blueprint as well to explain how the test is performed. And start the commit message with (WIP) to indicate it is work in progress.

For commits we don't wish to get merged, you may start the commit message with "DO NOT MERGE" like the one I did before[1], then explain the background in the commit message body as Ifat requested.

[1]: https://gerrit.opnfv.org/gerrit/#/c/27277/'}, {'account_id': 19159, 'date': '2017-11-23 16:13:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
py3: Fix encoding/decoding

Use to_utf8 from the oslo_serialization library to encode
bytestrings.

Change-Id: I4a2d6bf6354b1a80d15942deba374e09c8db2f20

commit_message:
Optimise: Use sqlalchemy to build table sequence

Used 'metadata.sorted_tables' to sort 'soft-delete' tables
in order of foreign key dependency.

The following existing functional test case ensures that this
change does not cause a regression:
'glance.tests.functional.db.base.DBPurgeTests.test_db_purge'

Change-Id: I334368c0de74f953aa877942569ddfa52defb028

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: Ie2bf2618c8e202653a45cde195bd395ab7058dc1

commit_message:
Add missing include of ironic::drivers::ansible

This manifest enables additional configuration of the ansible deploy,
and also ensures that required packages are installed.

Implements: blueprint ansible-deploy
Change-Id: I3a9d81cbae70a115c02b5bff8a62c30b38abd38a

[policy in code] Add support for replicas, networks and security services [7/10]

This patch adds policy in code support for replica, network
and security service resources.

Partial-Implements: blueprint policy-in-code

commit_message:
Finalize migration to keystoneauth adapters

removes code that allowed some service sections to not have and use
keystoneauth adapter options.

Also deprecates `[keystone]region_name` option in favor of per-client
option of the same name.

Change-Id: Ifd58947b016bfa93b516dd47a170ba8f5abf277e
Closes-Bug: #1699547

[{'created': '2017-12-15 16:53:29.000000000', 'message': 'Inital import of tripleo ansible inventory code

This is moved from tripleo-validations so we can make use of the
same code in tripleoclient for undercloud deploy, commit copied:

a1e9265 Merge "Fix include action DEPRECATION WARNING (Ansible >2.4)"

Note this doesn't currently move the inventory script, as we'll need
to adjust packaging and that's not strictly needed for the use
of the code in tripleoclient.

Change-Id: I03f609b8ff9f36c95a8382aa1705147d99cb973b
'}]
commit_message:
Inital import of tripleo ansible inventory code

This is moved from tripleo-validations so we can make use of the
same code in tripleoclient for undercloud deploy, commit copied:

a1e9265 Merge "Fix include action DEPRECATION WARNING (Ansible >2.4)"

Note this doesn't currently move the inventory script, as we'll need
to adjust packaging and that's not strictly needed for the use
of the code in tripleoclient.

Change-Id: I03f609b8ff9f36c95a8382aa1705147d99cb973b

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-07 17:21:19.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Consolidate serviceaccounts and restrict rbac

Currently, services have two serviceaccounts: one specified in the
chart that cannot read anything, and one injected via helm-toolkit
that can read everything.  This patch set sets up a mean to clean
up the two serviceaccounts and provides some logic to restrict the
resources that need readonly access in the rbac role.

Change-Id: I47d41e0cad9b5b002f59fc9652bad2cc025538dc
'}, {'created': '2017-12-12 22:43:45.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Consolidate serviceaccounts and restrict rbac

Currently, services have two serviceaccounts: one specified in the
chart that cannot read anything, and one injected via helm-toolkit
that can read everything.  This patch set sets up a mean to clean
up the two serviceaccounts and provides some logic to restrict the
resources that need readonly access in the rbac role.

Experimental: alert-manager

Change-Id: I47d41e0cad9b5b002f59fc9652bad2cc025538dc

Experimental: alert-manager

Change-Id: I47d41e0cad9b5b002f59fc9652bad2cc025538dc
'}, {'created': '2017-12-13 22:41:47.000000000', 'message': 'Consolidate serviceaccounts and restrict rbac

Currently, services have two serviceaccounts: one specified in the
chart that cannot read anything, and one injected via helm-toolkit
that can read everything. This patch set sets up a mean to solve the
following issues:

- Remove the need to mount and inject a separate and different SA.
- Current implementation of k8s leaves behind artifacts such as
  rolebindings from the second SA when the chart is deleted.
- This further restricts access to only resources the chart depends on.

Follow on patch sets will clean up the other charts and helm-toolkit.

A sample change is done to the redis chart.

Change-Id: I47d41e0cad9b5b002f59fc9652bad2cc025538dc

'}, {'created': '2017-12-15 19:26:46.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Consolidate serviceaccounts and restrict rbac

Currently, services have two serviceaccounts: one specified in the
chart that cannot read anything, and one injected via helm-toolkit
that can read everything. This patch set sets up a mean to solve the
following issues:

- Remove the need to mount and inject a separate and different SA.
- Current implementation of k8s leaves behind artifacts such as
  rolebindings from the second SA when the chart is deleted.
- This further restricts access to only resources the chart depends on.

Follow on patch sets will clean up the other charts and helm-toolkit.

A sample change is done to the redis chart.

commit_message:
RBAC: Consolidate serviceaccounts and restrict rbac

Currently, services have two serviceaccounts: one specified in the
chart that cannot read anything, and one injected via helm-toolkit
that can read everything. This patch set refactors the logic to:

- cleanup the roles and their binding automatically when the helm
  chart is deleted;
- remove the need to separately mount a serviceaccount  with secret;
- better handling of namespaces resource restriction.

Co-Authored-By: portdirect <pete@port.direct>

Change-Id: I47d41e0cad9b5b002f59fc9652bad2cc025538dc

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-02-02 16:54:03.000000000', 'message': 'Pin setuptools to 30.4.0

This pin prevents openstack.nose-plugin from breaking the
command line openstack client. This commit is exclusive to
the stable/mitaka branch because the problem does not occur
on Newton and later.

Change-Id: I61ee2b05cde6a0a048f5ad9ea336de678227a877
Closes-Bug: #1651292
'}]
commit_message:
Pin setuptools to 30.4.0

This pin prevents openstack.nose-plugin from breaking the
command line openstack client. This commit is exclusive to
the stable/mitaka branch because the problem does not occur
on Newton and later.

Change-Id: I61ee2b05cde6a0a048f5ad9ea336de678227a877
Closes-Bug: #1651292

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-01-02 10:38:46.000000000', 'message': "Explicitly start mysql server on ubuntu

The current code expects that MySql server will be up and running by
default, however, at certein deployments this is not the case.
The current patch will invoke a start on mysql server even if it's already
running (doesn't affect the running mysqld process).

Change-Id: I058a474622cfba989c50f8a7ba2d3a6c82267c02
"}, {'created': '2017-01-15 12:32:31.000000000', 'message': "Explicitly start mysql server on ubuntu

The current code expects that MySql server will be up and running by
default, however, at certein deployments this is not the case.

commit_message:
Explicitly start mysql server on ubuntu

The current code expects that MySql server will be up and running by
default, however, at certein deployments this is not the case.
The current patch will invoke a start on mysql server even if it's already
running

Change-Id: I058a474622cfba989c50f8a7ba2d3a6c82267c02

commit_message:
Drop MANIFEST.in - it's not needed by pbr

tacker already uses PBR:-
setuptools.setup(
	 setup_requires=['pbr>=1.8'],
	 pbr=True)

This patch removes `MANIFEST.in` file as pbr generates a
sensible manifest from git files and some standard files
and it removes the need for an explicit `MANIFEST.in` file.

Change-Id: I4181944c6ca639451de1772aa3d1ed449a5f4bc5

commit_message:
neutron: Allow new config path for metadata agent

Use the new neutron-metadata-agent config path when setting
up the agent. The new path simplifies the startup because
no configuration files must be given due to the automatic defaults
from oslo.config.

Change-Id: I1fa7a7bbb80d299a7ccd46ac600664a81dd96a82

I would prefer to see a complete solution, where we remove vxlan from the list of supported tunnel types, and *also* configure the agents correctly.'}, {'account_id': 4656, 'date': '2016-01-18 18:16:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Prevent tunnel creation when requested

Devstack should not create tunnels when either vlans
are requested or tunnels are specifically not requested.

Change-Id: Ida01aa4e1928912e20bf2ec9bf2d506692dffe07
Closes-Bug: 1403625

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-01-28 00:17:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified-1

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: I43828f47711118eba8d835222586db4faac93180
(cherry picked from commit 6817f0ac3a834385ee208ccad8a338cd3d0a6216)

commit_message:
Use Apache/mod_proxy as the TLS proxy instead of stud

Setting a proxy for a service is now a two-step process:

1. Add a configuration for the listener port using add_tls_proxy
2. Restart Apache using start_tls_proxy

Some services have multiple ports so this reduces the number
of Apache restarts required.

A template is used to generate configuration for each
service and is appended to tlsproxy.conf in the
appropriate Apache config subdir. This is still
readable and makes cleanup simpler.

No SSLCertificateChainFile/SSLCACertificateFile is set
because the devstack CA is added to the system bundle.

The SSL/TLS certificate generated by devstack is now
broken out into separate cert/key files for use by
Apache.

Add enable_mod_proxy function so Apache can act as a TLS proxy.

If the tlsproxy service is enabled then ensure that Apache,
mod_ssl and mod_proxy are all enabled. Don't rely on Keystone
to enable these.

Change-Id: Iafb2fa24b7738779c82171dfc57d43877c2e5ed6

commit_message:
Add 'hitch' support for 'tls-proxy' option.

As 'stud' used by 'tls-proxy' service was deprecated since Ubuntu xenial,
add 'hitch' support as a replacement of 'stud'.
Either of 'stud' or 'hitch' will be automatically selected depending on the distro release.

Change-Id: Ibcedcc0648d341d9d8280d113dd8e6b5ccd0af18
Closes-Bug: 1613071
Signed-off-by: Masanori Itoh <masanori.itoh@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2015-08-11 02:21:02.000000000', 'message': 'Fix cinder error when rejoin stack after system reboot

lvm volume is not started automatically after system reboot, so
cinder will complain volumes not found. This patch will try to
restart volumes when rejoining stack.

Change-Id: I488ad5d58d3bd06cb1e2c4ba304bee1f94ea6228
'}]
commit_message:
Fix cinder error when rejoin stack after system reboot

lvm volume is not started automatically after system reboot, so
cinder will complain volumes not found. This patch will try to
restart volumes when rejoining stack.

Change-Id: I488ad5d58d3bd06cb1e2c4ba304bee1f94ea6228

commit_message:
Adjust keystone permissions for ironic hypervisor

As part of adding policy support to Ironic, this change updates
the nova configuration for the ironic hypervisor to use the "nova"
service user, rather than "admin" user.

Change-Id: I8f7a9f97ebbbcfc3b9ab511c4b4098feea0e914d

commit_message:
Allow user to preallocate physical volume for LVM

* define function _pv_path
* correct variable names
* call _pv_path when looking up physical volume path for volume group

Change-Id: I5fe63e00244ebd4f585167b7e24ca9ab77600aba
Signed-off-by: C.J. Collier <cjcollier@linuxfoundation.org>

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-09-17 00:32:31.000000000', 'message': 'Allow for a new pseudo-service to init nova-db

Currently the way this logic works forces co-existence
of the n-api service and the db service, when really
they need not be on the same host.

Change-Id: I305f9cd209d70813b7a7f15974ec131bc32e4194
'}]
commit_message:
Allow for a new pseudo-service to init nova-db

Currently the way this logic works forces co-existence
of the n-api service and the db service, when really
they need not be on the same host.

Change-Id: I305f9cd209d70813b7a7f15974ec131bc32e4194

[{'created': '2016-06-28 08:44:16.000000000', 'message': 'Give an option for not setting requirement constraints

Projects sometimes want to run jobs without upper constraints.
Add a way to override this behaviour using an env variable.

Change-Id: Ia35ab8de4ed6487faf703cc36da3a183ac48a60d
'}]
commit_message:
Give an option for not setting requirement constraints

Projects sometimes want to run jobs without upper constraints.
Add a way to override this behaviour using an env variable.

Change-Id: Ia35ab8de4ed6487faf703cc36da3a183ac48a60d

* Install libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 in Ubuntu for python3
* If the pip_install function is called for a package instead of
  an OpenStack service, then install it on both python2 and python3.
  --upgrade will be forced in this case because we want the binaries

* Install libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 in Ubuntu for python3
* If the pip_install function is called for a package instead of

Depends-On: I25c46f2211af8075974a93acdf587cd059673bbb

commit_message:
Changes to get devstack working with python3

* Install libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 in Ubuntu for python3
* If the pip_install function is called for a package instead of
  an OpenStack service, then install it on both python2 and python3.
  --upgrade will be forced in this case because we want the binaries
  of Python3 to take precedence over the ones that are provided by
  Python2.

Depends-On: I25c46f2211af8075974a93acdf587cd059673bbb
Depends-On: Iab9c23e497956e45c5d04a3d6513acf1b026aafb
Depends-On: Ic3eff6609d35a756b8be7adf0557ce17d1465408

Change-Id: I4ca6366d4a4d1b007d12e7cd3975506e101d42c0

commit_message:
Add Oracle Linux 7 installation support to docs

The docs need to be updated to mention the fix to bug #1568634, which added
installation support for Oracle Linux 7.

Change-Id: Ic4a78d431349fb70cafa7a9a64eff83cb332743a
Closes-Bug: #1571394

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 4656, 'name': 'Sean M. Collins', 'email': 'sean@coreitpro.com', 'username': 'scollins'}, {'_account_id': 7118, 'name': 'Ian Wienand', 'email': 'iwienand@redhat.com', 'username': 'iwienand'}, {'_account_id': 10118, 'name': 'IBM PowerKVM CI', 'email': 'kvmpower@linux.vnet.ibm.com', 'username': 'powerkvm', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 10385, 'name': 'Citrix XenServer CI', 'username': 'citrix_xenserver_ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 16376, 'name': 'Intel NFV CI', 'email': 'openstack-nfv-ci@intel.com', 'username': 'intel-nfv-ci', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22305, 'name': 'Yinon', 'email': 'yinonby@hpe.com', 'username': 'yinonby'}, {'_account_id': 22342, 'name': 'Alon Kochba', 'email': 'alonko@hpe.com', 'username': 'alonko'}, {'_account_id': 22908, 'name': 'Koby Aizer', 'email': 'koby.aizer@hpe.com', 'username': 'kobya'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 22305, 'date': '2016-07-26 16:36:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 22908, 'date': '2016-07-26 16:51:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 22305, 'date': '2016-07-26 16:53:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 22305, 'date': '2016-07-26 16:54:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2016-07-26 19:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I realise this is relatively minor code, but I would not like to see this approach in devstack core.  The reason is that next thing you know this will be used in the gate and we'll be making it even harder to replicate gate failures than it already is by pulling in code changes outside our usual mechanisms.  The idea that "we're running $PROJECT, but with the XYZ company patch" where that patch is built & maintained outside the usual OpenStack review mechanism is not appealing.

I also realise nothing stops a plugin doing this anyway, but devstack does have to make decisions about what we support.

Our way of bringing in patches is really via the review mechanism [1].  With depends-on you can get cross-project dependencies.  if something isn't quite ready you can always wip it.  It's kind of the core thing about openstack that we all use gerrit and collaborate on changes.

I'm willing to listen to the use-case for this and maybe it's convincing ... but that's my first thought here.

[1] I'm not sure if you know this -- gerrit does its best to keep it hidden in the "Download" pull-down -- but you can pull this change into a tree with "git pull https://git.openstack.org/openstack-dev/devstack refs/changes/78/347478/2"'}, {'account_id': 22305, 'date': '2016-07-26 20:01:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> I realise this is relatively minor code, but I would not like to
 > see this approach in devstack core.  The reason is that next thing
 > you know this will be used in the gate and we'll be making it even
 > harder to replicate gate failures than it already is by pulling in
 > code changes outside our usual mechanisms.  The idea that "we're
 > running $PROJECT, but with the XYZ company patch" where that patch
 > is built & maintained outside the usual OpenStack review mechanism
 > is not appealing.
 > 
 > I also realise nothing stops a plugin doing this anyway, but
 > devstack does have to make decisions about what we support.
 > 
 > Our way of bringing in patches is really via the review mechanism
 > [1].  With depends-on you can get cross-project dependencies.  if
 > something isn't quite ready you can always wip it.  It's kind of
 > the core thing about openstack that we all use gerrit and
 > collaborate on changes.
 > 
 > I'm willing to listen to the use-case for this and maybe it's
 > convincing ... but that's my first thought here.
 > 
 > [1] I'm not sure if you know this -- gerrit does its best to keep
 > it hidden in the "Download" pull-down -- but you can pull this
 > change into a tree with "git pull https://git.openstack.org/openstack-dev/devstack
 > refs/changes/78/347478/2"

Hi Ian,

While I agree that patches/fixes should always go to gerrit, the process is sometimes too long. Some projects don't have many reviewers, and sometimes it just takes time until a fix is committed, and it is obviously impossible to work with devstack if you have to wait for a fix. I do believe, that everyone that uses devstack to do something more than trivial, has something similar to this commit.
If we want devstack users to be satisfied, we must solve the problem of waiting for commits.
In our company, waiting for a fix-commit is simply not an option. So we do whatever we can, in order to push forward the fix-commit, but we can't stop testing/developing until it is committed.
We have already been using this patch_plugins method for a while now, and we just wanted to share it with the community, as we are certain it will benefit from it.
I totally agree about the gating comment - If gates run with different commits, it will definitely make it harder to reproduce bugs, but again - If the gate cannot run because it is waiting for a fix, and the fix-commit is taking time, what is the point of the gate? As you said - whoever is running the gate will do it anyway if they want to, so better standardize it. Maybe we can even find a way to have a gate output whatever patches it was running with (if it was running with).

That said, I'm always open to other suggestions, especially if they are better :-)'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2016-07-26 20:33:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> it is obviously impossible to work with devstack if you have to wait for a fix.

I'm not sure I would agree with this; fundamentally we are using source from git and thus the thing it does really well is manage changes.

It may not be totally obvious -- git links are hard to find on gerrit, maybe we don't document it well in devstack.  it's still not quite clear to me exactly what workflow is holding you up and requiring patches.  it might be we just need better documentation to help expose how to best use the tools we have"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-07-26 21:59:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Hi Ian,

Thanks for you comments, I agree we might be missing something here. I'd like to give three use cases and be happy to hear if there is a better way to handle them:

First use is pretty much what Yinon has mentioned before. Assuming you have changes to one of the devstack plugins, and you've published the review. Until it is merged, what are your options to use it when running devstack? You were suggesting that you can pull the change from gerrit "Download" link, but how can you apply this to the relevant repository (giving that devstack is cloning the plugins repositories on its own).

Second use case is that you're currently developing a code to one of the plugins which is still work-in-progress. How can you apply you're (partial) code changes in order to test them?

Third use case is similar to #1, but assuming you need to use code from several different pending reviews.'}, {'account_id': 4656, 'date': '2016-08-01 19:47:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I don't think this is something we should support. There are ways that people can pull in branches, via the *_GIT_REPO and *_BRANCH configuration variables."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 04:58:24.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-12-20 03:12:21.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

This isn't a path we'd go down.  Removing from the queue, thanks"}]

commit_message:
Support patching projects/plugins

Add a patching mechanism right after cloning the
projects and fetching plugins, in order to allow the
user to supply patches. User will place his patches
under a "patches" directory under the devstack root
directory. The patch name will start with the name of
the project/plugin, and end with ".patch", and between
the user can put a string to identify the patch.

Change-Id: Ie28e1f8dda4ea138f08a3a8e3962bdfbe7ec2b06
Closes-Bug: #1606625

commit_message:
WIP - Install nginx with neutron, for metadata proxy

Neutron will soon allow the use of nginx for the per namespace
metadata proxy, due to memory usage issues with that many
python interpreters at scale.

WIP while I test things out in both places.

Change-Id: I3810f02f10c37fecce86dfe4072b1a2ffd800634
Depends-On: I86c2ef928c7b0aa6a98a8cb2e225b21dbeb78887

I totally get why that's annoying ... but in the logs you now get a whole bunch of 

 2016-10-07 04:52:52.059 | +++ lib/apache:source:22                     :   set +o
 2016-10-07 04:52:52.059 | +++ lib/apache:source:22                     :   grep xtrace
 2016-10-07 04:52:52.062 | ++ lib/apache:source:22                     :   _XTRACE_LIB_APACHE='set -o xtrace'
 2016-10-07 04:52:52.063 | ++ lib/apache:source:23                     :   set +o xtrace

the whole point of this xtrace swizzling is that we're trying to find balance between usability/debugability and useless log spew.  So this re-introduces a bunch of boiler place noise back into the logs which hurts signal to noise ratio.

we could tighten the regex i suppose ... but is it worth it?  trying to find a balance between the noise in thousands of logs per day v the chance someone hits this"}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2016-10-10 15:23:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I totally get why that's annoying ... but in the logs you now get a
 > whole bunch of
 > 
 > 2016-10-07 04:52:52.059 | +++ lib/apache:source:22                 
 >    :   set +o
 > 2016-10-07 04:52:52.059 | +++ lib/apache:source:22                 
 >    :   grep xtrace
 > 2016-10-07 04:52:52.062 | ++ lib/apache:source:22                  
 >   :   _XTRACE_LIB_APACHE='set -o xtrace'
 > 2016-10-07 04:52:52.063 | ++ lib/apache:source:23                  
 >   :   set +o xtrace
 > 
 > the whole point of this xtrace swizzling is that we're trying to
 > find balance between usability/debugability and useless log spew. 
 > So this re-introduces a bunch of boiler place noise back into the
 > logs which hurts signal to noise ratio.
 > 
 > we could tighten the regex i suppose ... but is it worth it? 
 > trying to find a balance between the noise in thousands of logs per
 > day v the chance someone hits this

I guess I am not a fan of "special cases". Why is xtrace so special? Why aren't other things ignored?

Considering how large the logs are already, I'm not sure what impact having these lines in the logfile is going to have.

It just really bothers me that things can silently be thrown away from the logfile. As happened to me. Luckily I was able to figure out why after wandering from project to project. But others may not be so lucky.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2016-10-12 00:14:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I guess I am not a fan of "special cases". Why is xtrace so special? Why aren't other things ignored?

It's completely arbitrary, but practical in the sense that we try to balance unnecessary noise in the logs and information.  That's why we have a the xtrace on/off stuff at all -- it's hard enough to debug failures without (literally) hundreds/thousands of lines of boilerplate stuff to filter out.  this is filtering out very common boilerplate stuff that's in every file. 

> It just really bothers me that things can silently be thrown away from the logfile. As happened to me. Luckily I was able to figure out why after wandering from project to project. But others may not be so lucky.

I get it, but this just puts noise in the logs.  if you feel motivated enough to make it so that we don't put this noise in the logs, but still handle the case you faced, i think that's moving in the right direction.  adding useless stuff to the logs doesn't, IMO'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2016-10-12 03:01:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2016-10-12 03:37:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2016-10-12 03:47:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2016-10-12 03:50:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

@Ian,

Doing some measurements and I was surprised that the regex eliminates about 17% of the logfile line count! That seems like a lot to me.

So I agree the skipping is a good thing. I am proposing adding a notice to the logfile to inform the user about this skipping.

Thanks for your help.'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2016-10-12 04:06:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-12 05:31:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified+1

regular expression. At the bottom provide statistics on how many lines
were skipped based on the regex match.

Change-Id: I493014adf2a5a7325d5baa5f27592fa2239f1ab9
"}]
commit_message:
WIP/DNM: Leave me alone, I'm concentrating...

Don't merge of course

Inform user that the logfile skips lines matching regex

Provide a notice at the top and bottom of the logfile informing the user
that the logfile does not print content that matches the specified
regular expression. At the bottom provide statistics on how many lines
were skipped based on the regex match.

Change-Id: I493014adf2a5a7325d5baa5f27592fa2239f1ab9

commit_message:
DNM: Test with python 3.4 enabled

Try and get to a full devstack run with python 3 enabled(ie clients and
projects with the python 3 classifiers use python 3).

Once gate jobs succeed and the corresponding python libraries are fixed and
released, they'll be added as a non-voting job or as experimental jobs to
respective projects.

Change-Id: I3a1dfde76009cbac1d419e0ff3f1d20c4a2e99c3

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

commit_message:
Fix the way to get backup metadata

In v3/shell.py do_backup_update(), the metadata through
'args.metadata' is a list, like this: 'metadata': [u'k1=v1'].
But we need a metadata dict like this: 'metadata': {"k1": "v1"}.
So call the right method shell_utils.extract_metadata()
to get metadata from args.

Change-Id: I82cb96b1f89b4009d4b3f4a0e64db076a7a04977

commit_message:
Update cinder info when attach volume that attached

If you attach a volume to two instances, you will
see that the state of the volume is always attaching.
The cause of this bug is 8831f3d0. The state of the
volume should not be used to determine whether or not
the cinder is called.

Closes-Bug: #1736874

Change-Id: I98f22f6988b0a449257493bb9f2b4c7250b8b03a

commit_message:
Modify the notes of upload_image_data() method

The notes of upload_image_data() method in
zun.image.galnce.driver should be "Upload an image." .

commit_message:
Add preserve_on_delete field in requested_network when attach network

Attaching a container to a neutron network failed with KeyError
on retrieving the 'preserve_on_delete' key from the requested
network. This is because the latest code change in kuryr_network.py
assumes the 'preserve_on_delete' key is presented but this key is
missing.

Change-Id: I3e3a1dc35227d4f469619bb8eb9215ca49b3343f
Closes-bug: #1737687

commit_message:
Replace jsonutils by common json package

This PS is going to following item:

- Remove dependency oslo.serialization which only use at one test-case
  and use build-in python package that is json[1] in the code-base.
- Ignore N521 check in the flake which no longer need to check when we
  change into json.

[1] https://docs.python.org/3.6/library/json.html

Change-Id: I22cf66d1ea5666a072a06456213a7964c5deced8

and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: I43828f47711118eba8d835222586db4faac93180
(cherry picked from commit 6817f0ac3a834385ee208ccad8a338cd3d0a6216)

commit_message:
Avoid tox_install.sh for constraints support

We do not need tox_install.sh, pip can handle constraints itself
and install the project correctly. Thus update tox.ini and remove
the now obsolete tools/tox_install.sh file.

This follows https://review.openstack.org/#/c/508061 to remove
tools/tox_install.sh.

Change-Id: I387f9aa8a44a7bb0908097f799b98990989b18db

commit_message:
Add accessbot for #openstack-vpnaas

The Neutron VirtualPrivateNetwork-as-a-Service team is diverging a bit
from the rest of the Neutron team.
In order not to clutter the overall #openstack-neutron channel,
and to serve the VPNaaS team as it continues to diverge from Neutron,
we would like the #openstack-vpnaas channel logged.

Change-Id: I344aee655560f98205afe10895a331fc04403864
Depends-on: I8c89a62566fdb332450b07448e96058933852675

(1 comment)

Nice catch, adding a test to expose this via the API should be pretty easy. We should also be sure to add a release note with links to the bug fix so that operators know this is changing, even if it is going from 500 -> 400.

https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/contributor/release-notes.html'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-11-23 03:12:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-11-23 14:49:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

This looks good. One common pattern you see when reviewing or writing patches that expose issues is landing the bug that exposes the bug first. Then when the patch with the fix lands, all you have to do is remove the wip decorator from the test case.

This makes things super convenient for reviewers because they can see the expected behavior documented in the test case and that it fails (because of the WIP decorator). Then they can step through the fix and see it fixes the issue with the removal of the decorator.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-11-24 01:12:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

 > 
 > This makes things super convenient for reviewers because they can
 > see the expected behavior documented in the test case and that it
 > fails (because of the WIP decorator). Then they can step through
 > the fix and see it fixes the issue with the removal of the
 > decorator.

Oh, sorry that I misunderstood before.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-11-24 01:22:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-11-24 01:34:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Patch Set 4 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-11-24 01:35:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Published edit on patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-11-24 01:35:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

I think it is the correct way now. Right?'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-11-24 14:50:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

Nice job, thanks for reworking this!'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2017-12-01 13:46:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
Add schema check for OS-TRUST:trust authentication

If the OS-TRUST:trust is not a dict when authenticating,
Keystone will raise 500 error. This patch add the
related schema check to avoid the error.

Change-Id: I575440fa507c5274e0c3bc09f4cfcb9b3d91a28c
Closes-bug: #1733754

[{'created': '2017-11-22 18:50:10.000000000', 'message': "Expose a bug when authenticating for a trust-scoped token

The test added here should pass with a 400 Bad Request, but keystone
doesn't validate the OS-TRUST:trust key of the authentication request
is actually a dictionary. As a result, it assumes it is a dictionary
and attempts to use dictionary methods on. This results in a 500
Internal Server Error when it should really be a 400 Bad Request.

A subsequent patch can fix this by enhancing the jsonschema
definition for token authentication.

commit_message:
Expose a bug when authenticating for a trust-scoped token

The test added here should pass with a 400 Bad Request, but keystone
doesn't validate the OS-TRUST:trust key of the authentication request
is actually a dictionary. As a result, it assumes it is a dictionary
and attempts to use dictionary methods on. This results in a 500
Internal Server Error when it should really be a 400 Bad Request.

A subsequent patch can fix this by enhancing the jsonschema
definition for token authentication.

Change-Id: I9ea118945870f27dd73000b45673d966ea05ca53
Partial-Bug: #1733754

commit_message:
Stage openstack config files

Stage config files from openstack and all projects used by the
devstack run.

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-10 18:11:46.000000000', 'message': 'Improve exception logging with 500 response

Currently when keystone throws a 500 Error, depending on the actual
exception type, it can log the message as an exception or as a warning.

Specifically, if the server throws an exception.UnexpectedError, it
does not log this as an exception; it simply logs it as a warning. This
patch set logs the error as an exception if exception.Error is an
exception.UnexpectedError.

Change-Id: Ia47cc11378ec64d59b7403cb8a284c764148d7a9
Co-Authored-By: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>
'}, {'created': '2017-12-10 19:38:16.000000000', 'message': 'Improve exception logging with 500 response

Currently when keystone throws a 500 Error, depending on the actual
exception type, it can log the message as an exception or as a warning.

Specifically, if the server throws an exception.UnexpectedError, it
does not log this as an exception; it simply logs it as a warning. This
patch set logs the error as an exception if exception.Error is an
exception.UnexpectedError.

Change-Id: Ia47cc11378ec64d59b7403cb8a284c764148d7a9
Co-Authored-By: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>
Closes-Bug: #1717962
'}]
commit_message:
Improve exception logging with 500 response

Currently when keystone throws a 500 Error, depending on the actual
exception type, it can log the message as an exception or as a warning.

Specifically, if the server throws an exception.UnexpectedError, it
does not log this as an exception; it simply logs it as a warning. This
patch set logs the error as an exception if exception.Error is an
exception.UnexpectedError.

Change-Id: Ia47cc11378ec64d59b7403cb8a284c764148d7a9
Co-Authored-By: Tin Lam <tin@irrational.io>
Closes-Bug: #1717962

commit_message:
Switch to use _get_subnet_object() in ipam_backend_mixin module

This patch switches to use _get_subnet_object() instead of
_get_subnet() method in ipam_backend_mixin module to use Subnet
OVO instead of db model class directly.

Change-Id: Ibdc91ba20b560dc42319565b5f4aeadba0dfcb29
Partially-Implements: blueprint adopt-oslo-versioned-objects-for-db

commit_message:
Fixes Bug1683228

create_from_image() function checks for free space in conversion path
(by default /var/lib/cinder/conversion) even if cinder is creating
volume from image snapshot.

If /var/lib/cinder/conversion has less free space than the size of the
image volume is created from, exception will be thrown by
check_available_space() function in image_utils module.

This patch checks if cinder is configured with
allowed_direct_url_schemes = cinder
If so, cinder should not check free space in conversion path because
volume is created from image snapshot.

Change-Id: I13d2e6aefda6b0ab40bba12e485f97f1c08438e8

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-11 19:48:29.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Save driver_volume_type when refreshing attachment connection_info

With the new cinder volume attachment flow, during a resize the
source compute will create a new volume attachment for any BDMs
connected to the instance and delete the existing volume attachments
which represents the connection to the source host. The finish_resize
flow on the destination compute will then refresh the connection info
on the BDMs it's working with before passing them to the virt driver.

Since the source compute updated the BDM.attachment_id to point at
the new attachment which is meant for the destination host, the
refresh_connection_info call will get the connection_info for the new
reserved attachment, which is actually empty since it hasn't been
connected to the destination host yet. This results in wiping out the
BDM.connection_info which has the "driver_volume_type" value which is
something the virt driver on the destination compute needs to know
which volume backend driver to use to connect the volume to the
destination host.

We work around this by saving off the driver_volume_type when
refreshing the connection_info from the new attachment in case
the new attachment's connection_info doesn't have driver_volume_type
set.

This really seems like something the volume attachments API in
Cinder should be modeling for us, but doing that requires an API
change in Cinder so we have to work around this in Nova for now.

Change-Id: Ifc80d07d94311534fd9e7824ede9d09223a011c2
Closes-Bug: #1737599
'}, {'created': '2017-12-11 21:06:41.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Update and complete volume attachments during resize

With the new cinder volume attachment flow, during a resize the
source compute will create a new volume attachment for any BDMs
connected to the instance and delete the existing volume attachments
which represents the connection to the source host. The finish_resize
flow on the destination compute will then refresh the connection info
on the BDMs it's working with before passing them to the virt driver.

Since the source compute updated the BDM.attachment_id to point at
the new attachment which is meant for the destination host, the
refresh_connection_info call will get the connection_info for the new
reserved attachment, which is actually empty since it hasn't been
connected to the destination host yet. This results in wiping out the
BDM.connection_info which has the "driver_volume_type" value which is
something the virt driver on the destination compute needs to know
which volume backend driver to use to connect the volume to the
destination host.

This change updates the volume attachments on the destination host
before refreshing the connection_info in the BDMs and before we call
the driver to finish the resize, and then we also complete the
volume attachments once the driver has successfully finished the
resize. This is similar to what would happen via _prep_block_device
during the initial instance create, but since the code paths into the
driver are different we have to handle this explicitly in the compute
manager.

Closes-Bug: #1737599

Change-Id: Ifc80d07d94311534fd9e7824ede9d09223a011c2
'}, {'created': '2017-12-12 02:50:32.000000000', 'message': 'Update and complete volume attachments during resize

during the initial instance create, but since the code paths into the

manager.

Similarly, we have to perform the same incantation when reverting a
resize and going back to the original source host.

Closes-Bug: #1737599

commit_message:
Update and complete volume attachments during resize

With the new cinder volume attachment flow, during a resize the
source compute will create a new volume attachment for any BDMs
connected to the instance and delete the existing volume attachments
which represents the connection to the source host. The finish_resize
flow on the destination compute will then refresh the connection info
on the BDMs it's working with before passing them to the virt driver.

Since the source compute updated the BDM.attachment_id to point at
the new attachment which is meant for the destination host, the
refresh_connection_info call will get the connection_info for the new
reserved attachment, which is actually empty since it hasn't been
connected to the destination host yet. This results in wiping out the
BDM.connection_info which has the "driver_volume_type" value which is
something the virt driver on the destination compute needs to know
which volume backend driver to use to connect the volume to the
destination host.

This change updates the volume attachments on the destination host
before refreshing the connection_info in the BDMs and before we call
the driver to finish the resize, and then we also complete the
volume attachments once the driver has successfully finished the
resize. This is similar to what would happen via _prep_block_device
during the initial instance create, but since the code paths into the
driver are different we have to handle this explicitly in the compute
manager.

Similarly, we have to perform the same incantation when reverting a
resize and going back to the original source host.

Closes-Bug: #1737599

Change-Id: Ifc80d07d94311534fd9e7824ede9d09223a011c2

commit_message:
Remove the objects for describing the extension for v2.1 API

The ControllerExtension, ResourceExtension objects, V21APIExtensionBase
are used for describing the extension. The v2.1 API already moves to the
plain route list, so those objects are useless now.

Partial implementation of blueprint api-extensions-merge-queens
Change-Id: I15b52d217cb287406a965dd2965c47ef2f5dab20

commit_message:
Remove the objects which related to the old v2 API implementation

The old v2 API implementation is removed since Mitaka. There are still
have some old v2 API objects for loading extension, extension API controller,
and describe the API extension in the tree, so clean up them.

Also remove the fake extension Foxinsocks which is used to legacy v2 testing,
but it is useless now.

Partial implement of blueprint api-extensions-merge-queens
Change-Id: I8c814c756c7733669a8880ddc183a1b062cc55e0

commit_message:
Throw OpenStackCloudCreateException on create errors

The exception is OpenStackCloudCreateException, not
OpenStackCloudCreationException.

Change-Id: Ia1bad2e279ed472d93c818d07a1d6de8723ab151

commit_message:
Deduplicate instance.create notification samples

This patch refactors the sample files of instance.create notifications.
As these notifications use a different payload class as the most of the
instance notifications a new common payload sample fragment was also
needed.

commit_message:
Improve Neutron driver _get_resource()

* Add support to resource names that contain underscores (e.g. qos_policy)
* Update _get_resources_by_filters to return a list of matches
  by default.
* Add mock constants

Change-Id: Idc193a2ba7df29025b12da8335efebb8d6b4b5af

subject: Remove /ironic-python-agent/api/app.wsgi
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 6618, 'name': 'Ruby Loo', 'email': 'opensrloo@gmail.com', 'username': 'rloo'}, {'_account_id': 6637, 'name': 'Sam Betts', 'email': 'sam@code-smash.net', 'username': 'sambetts'}, {'_account_id': 10239, 'name': 'Dmitry Tantsur', 'email': 'dtantsur@protonmail.com', 'username': 'dtantsur'}, {'_account_id': 11076, 'name': 'Shivanand Tendulker', 'email': 'stendulker@gmail.com', 'username': 'stendulker'}, {'_account_id': 11655, 'name': 'Julia Kreger', 'email': 'juliaashleykreger@gmail.com', 'username': 'jkreger', 'status': 'On the moon! With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 12356, 'name': 'Vladyslav Drok', 'email': 'vdrok@mirantis.com', 'username': 'vdrok'}, {'_account_id': 14525, 'name': 'Vasyl Saienko', 'email': 'vsaienko@mirantis.com', 'username': 'vsaienko'}, {'_account_id': 14760, 'name': 'John L. Villalovos', 'email': 'openstack.org@sodarock.com', 'username': 'jlvillal'}, {'_account_id': 19554, 'name': 'Nam', 'email': 'namnh68@fsoft.com.vn', 'username': 'namnh'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25903, 'name': 'Vu Cong Tuan', 'email': 'tuanvc@vn.fujitsu.com', 'username': 'tuanvu'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 25903, 'date': '2017-11-28 08:29:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19554, 'date': '2017-12-14 06:17:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

it should be gotten attention from core-reviewers.'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2017-12-14 07:07:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

app.wsgi in an empty file. Why do we need to pep8 it?

We probably should delete it.'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2017-12-14 07:10:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Nam,

I see you added all the core reviewers to this patch.

I'm not sure what others think. But I personally don't think we should just add all core reviewers to a patch because we want to. Others may disagree with me though. If there is a specific reviewer that a patch is relevant to, then I can see doing that. But just doing a shotgun approach and adding everybody I don't agree with."}, {'account_id': 25903, 'date': '2017-12-14 07:28:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 25903, 'date': '2017-12-14 07:32:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi John L. Villalovos,
I just want to make sure for whatever changes in the future, it should pass pep8 checks, like [1], [2], [3].
Anyway, the patch set has just been updated as your recommendation.
Thank you very much.
[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523333/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523334/
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/521244/'}, {'account_id': 19554, 'date': '2017-12-14 07:39:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@John L. Villalovos

Hi John, I am sorry about that.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2017-12-14 10:41:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> I personally don't think we should just add all core reviewers to a patch because we want to

+1"}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2017-12-14 15:17:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2017-12-14 15:18:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2017-12-14 16:05:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi

> I just want to make sure for whatever changes in the future, it should
> pass pep8 checks

EVERYONE that submits a patch, needs cores to actually approve and get the patch merged. This isn't any different from the other patches that are submitted; please do not explicitly add the cores as reviewers."}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2017-12-14 16:15:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Hi,

> I just want to make sure for whatever changes in the future, it should
> pass pep8 checks

I actually had a question about this wsgi stuff in [1] and I didn't get an answer. Maybe no one saw my comment. I'm -1'ing this cuz I'm curious still and would like an answer, even though this patch isn't doing that any more.

pep8 works on our python files even though we didn't explicitly specify those files. However, we do have a list of files to exclude. HOW do you know that .wsgi was not being pep8'd? It seems odd to me to have both a 'exclude =' and a 'filename = '...

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523337/"}, {'account_id': 25903, 'date': '2017-12-15 03:56:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Ruby,
Have a nice day.
Sorry because I missed the email notification for your question.
Unfortunately, I don't have the answer, either.
HOW do I know that .wsgi was not being pep8'd?
=> Well, I just tried to edit that file in a way which violates pep8 on purpose and noticed that all the tests for pep8 still passed.
After adding filename in tox, pep8 tests failed as expected.
Hopefully we could have the answer from someone, maybe other core reviewers."}, {'account_id': 14760, 'date': '2017-12-15 05:31:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Hi,
 > 
 > > I just want to make sure for whatever changes in the future, it
 > should
 > > pass pep8 checks
 > 
 > I actually had a question about this wsgi stuff in [1] and I didn't
 > get an answer. Maybe no one saw my comment. I'm -1'ing this cuz I'm
 > curious still and would like an answer, even though this patch
 > isn't doing that any more.
 > 
 > pep8 works on our python files even though we didn't explicitly
 > specify those files. However, we do have a list of files to
 > exclude. HOW do you know that .wsgi was not being pep8'd? It seems
 > odd to me to have both a 'exclude =' and a 'filename = '...
 > 
 > [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523337/

It is because of 'flake8'

http://flake8.pycqa.org/en/latest/user/options.html

Look for '--filename'

Default is '*.py'"}, {'account_id': 25903, 'date': '2017-12-15 06:07:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi John L. Villalovos,
Thanks a lot for your explanation :)'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2017-12-19 15:45:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: -Code-Review

Thanks John, for explaining.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2017-12-19 22:34:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2017-12-19 22:35:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

IPA is intended to be an embedded service, and as such I feel we shouldn't have this file presentl."}, {'account_id': 12356, 'date': '2017-12-19 22:43:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

Make whitelist externals os agnostic

eliminate the following warning:
WARNING:test command found but not installed in testenv

commit_message:
clean up non-install parts of contributor docs

- remove specific comments about preferring notifications v. polling
just say, polling can add load
- remove kafka publisher reference
- remove database publisher reference
- move key links (wiki, launchpad, ml, etc...) to index
- put all meter details in one area
- clean up testing

Change-Id: I1993a9945334ffe631f2ddb3dcd0316d0e71f258

[{'created': '2017-12-14 10:16:09.000000000', 'message': "Fix possible TypeError in VIF.fixed_ips

The VIF['network'] field can be initialized to None and therefore
a later call to VIF.fixed_ips() could raise a TypeError. This problem
was visible during AttachInterfacesTestJSON tempest test case when
nova tried to emit instance.interfacae_attach notification.

This patch checks makes sure that if VIF['network'] is None then
VIF.fixed_ips() return an empty list instead of raising a TypeError.

Change-Id: Ib285d874b19be5bc1dbcd1d2af32e461f67e34cb
Closes-Bug: #1737201
"}]
commit_message:
Fix possible TypeError in VIF.fixed_ips

The VIF['network'] field can be initialized to None and therefore
a later call to VIF.fixed_ips() could raise a TypeError. This problem
was visible during AttachInterfacesTestJSON tempest test case when
nova tried to emit instance.interfacae_attach notification.

This patch checks makes sure that if VIF['network'] is None then
VIF.fixed_ips() return an empty list instead of raising a TypeError.

Change-Id: Ib285d874b19be5bc1dbcd1d2af32e461f67e34cb
Closes-Bug: #1737201

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-12-07 20:38:40.000000000', 'message': 'Update nova-status and docs for nova-compute requiring placement 1.14

With change I2f367b06e683ed7c815dd9e0536a46e5f0a27e6c, nova-compute
now unconditionally requires Placement 1.14 to be available (the
client side code doesn't check to see if 1.14 is available before
trying to use it).

This change updates the nova-status check for the minimum required
version of Placement and also starts the "Queens" section of the
Placement upgrade notes docs.

We might need to update these again later, but as of today this
is what we need, and we'll update the release notes when we get
closer to Queens RC1 (we don't want to say in the release notes
that we require 1.14 today if we are going to require, e.g. 1.16,
a month from now).

Change-Id: I37415e384d375bc9b548a0223f787a9236286bb0
'}, {'created': '2017-12-13 20:53:14.000000000', 'message': 'Update nova-status and docs for nova-compute requiring placement 1.14

With change I2f367b06e683ed7c815dd9e0536a46e5f0a27e6c, nova-compute
now unconditionally requires Placement 1.14 to be available (the
client side code doesn't check to see if 1.14 is available before
trying to use it).

This change updates the nova-status check for the minimum required
version of Placement and also starts the "Queens" section of the
Placement upgrade notes docs.

Change-Id: I37415e384d375bc9b548a0223f787a9236286bb0
'}]
commit_message:
Update nova-status and docs for nova-compute requiring placement 1.14

With change I2f367b06e683ed7c815dd9e0536a46e5f0a27e6c, nova-compute
now unconditionally requires Placement 1.14 to be available (the
client side code doesn't check to see if 1.14 is available before
trying to use it).

This change updates the nova-status check for the minimum required
version of Placement and also starts the "Queens" section of the
Placement upgrade notes docs.

Change-Id: I37415e384d375bc9b548a0223f787a9236286bb0

commit_message:
[placement] Separate API schemas (resource_class)

In compute APIs, they have their schemas in the
independent directory (nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas).
Placement APIs should be like that as well.

This patch separates API schemas to an independent directory
(nova/api/openstack/placement/schemas)
from nova/api/openstack/placement/handlers/resource_class.py.

Subsequent patches will move schemas of other handlers.

Change-Id: I61bfc96953d1158d3204d3f578a5255c18af2d6e
